bibliographic_metadata.Title: Interpretable machine learning for mineral prospectivity mapping in the Qulong–Jiama district, Tibet, China
bibliographic_metadata.Author: Nini Mou, Emmanuel John M. Carranza, Jianling Xue, Shuai Zhang, Gongwen Wang, Hao Song, Yuhao Chen, Xiangning Ren

abstract: Machine learning (ML) models have been successfully adopted to delineate prospecting regions for a specific type of mineral deposit in data-driven mineral prospectivity mapping (MPM). The primary objective of the ML-based MPM is to effectively integrate multi-source mineral exploration information and enhance its predictive capability and precision. This study employs Random Forest (RF), Support Vector Machine (SVM), and Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) to conduct mineral prospectivity maps, utilizing interpretable machine learning techniques to improve model explainability and performance.
methodology: supervised > tree-based > random forest; supervised > kernel-based > support vector machine; supervised > neural networks > feedforward neural network (MLP)
key_points: Employs interpretable machine learning techniques to enhance mineral prospectivity mapping.
Utilizes Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, and Multi-Layer Perceptron for model construction.
Achieves high predictive performance with an AUC value of 0.970.
Identifies key evidence layers contributing to mineralization predictions.
Optimizes exploration targeting criteria based on coherent training samples.
